title: Who are the best NASCAR drivers at seasons end in the next-gen era?
text:
The NASCAR season is 36 races long. Drivers experience different momentum swings from crashing out consistently, having a winning streak, having a top ten finish streak and more. The final five races of the season provide an interesting stretch of data that will be dubbed “crunch time.”
In 2022 NASCAR introduced the next-gen car. This car completely changed how the cars looked and raced. Since then, the top drivers have changed, and a new era of drivers has emerged. Taking the final five races of every season since 2022 will provide the parameters needed to find which driver is the best during “crunch time.”
Manufacturers are further way to breakdown which driver is doing better in “crunch time.” Using the previously outlined standards William Byron (gold for Chevy) leads the way with an impressive average finish of 7.06. Joey Logano (blue for Ford) on back is where the average finish margin narrows. Christopher Bell (red for Toyota) sits fourth on this metric with an average finish of 10.20.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(janitor)
library(ggbump)
library(gt)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

nextgen<-read_csv("NASCAR Next-Gen Stats Final 5 Races.csv")

nextgen <- nextgen |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  remove_empty(which = c("rows", "cols"))

Encoding(nextgen$driver) <- "latin1"

nextgen$driver <- iconv(nextgen$driver, "latin1", "ASCII", sub="")

driverstats<-nextgen|>
  group_by(driver)|>
  summarise(
    Start = mean(start),
    Finish = mean(position)
  )
top10drivers <- driverstats |>
  arrange(Finish) |>  
  slice_head(n = 10)

top10drivers|> 
gt()|>
  cols_label(
    driver = "Driver",
    Start = "Average Start",
    Finish = "Average Finish"
    )|>
    tab_header(
    title = "William Byron has the best average in crunch time",
    subtitle = "William Byron has the best Chevy average finish. Joey Logano has the top Ford average finish. Denny Hamlin has the top Toyota average finish."
  )|>  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|> tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Blake Mace  |  **Source:** Racing Reference")
  )|> tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   )|>  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none")|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = driver == "Christopher Bell")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "blue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = driver == "Joey Logano")
  )|>tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "gold"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = driver == "William Byron")
  )

William Byron has the best Chevy average finish. Joey Logano has the top Ford average finish. Denny Hamlin has the top Toyota average finish.

Using the same statistics of average start and average finish William Byron has the third best average start and the best average finish among the group. Six drivers (Byron, Ryan Blaney, Kevin Harvick, Logano, Denny Hamlin and A.J. Allmendinger) are finishing better than their average starting position while the four drivers (Ross Chastain, Kyle Larson, Christopher Bell and Bubba Wallace) are finishing worse than their average starting position.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=top10drivers, 
    aes(y=driver, x=Finish, xend=Start),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red")+
    scale_x_reverse()+
   labs(
    title="William Byron Is The Best At Finishing Better Than He Started. ", 
    subtitle = "If a drivers <span style = 'color:green;'>finish</span> is on the right, that's good. If a drivers <span style = 'color:red;'>start</span> is on the right, that's bad.",
    caption="Source: Racing Reference | By: Blake Mace"
  ) +
   theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title=element_text(size=15, face="bold"),
    plot.subtitle=element_textbox_simple(),
    panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),
    plot.title.position="plot" 
  )









Kyle Larson is a fitting example of leading laps does not equal to the best average finish. Christopher Bell is another driver who has led a lot of laps and does not have the finishes to show for it. Ryan Blaney is unlike Larson and Bell and finishes better than he starts.


Code
lapleaders <- nextgen|>
  group_by(driver) |>
  summarise(
    total_laps_led = sum(led)
  ) |> 
  arrange(desc(total_laps_led))

top10lapleaders <- lapleaders |> 
  slice_head(n = 10)

cb <- top10lapleaders |> filter(grepl("Christopher Bell", driver) == TRUE)
rb <- top10lapleaders |> filter(grepl("Ryan Blaney", driver) == TRUE)
kl <- top10lapleaders |> filter(grepl("Kyle Larson", driver) == TRUE)
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data = top10lapleaders, aes(x=reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill = "gray")+
  geom_bar(data=cb, aes(x = reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill ="red")+
  geom_bar(data=rb, aes(x = reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill="blue")+
  geom_bar(data=kl, aes(x = reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill= "gold")+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(
    x="Driver", 
    y="Total Laps Led", 
    title="Kyle Larson has led the most laps in the final five races of the next-gen era.", 
    subtitle="The top drivers for each manufacturer changes.", 
    caption="Source: Racing Reference | By Blake Mace"
  )+
  theme(
    plot.title=element_text(size=10, face="bold"),
    plot.subtitle=element_textbox_simple(),
    panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),
    plot.title.position="plot"
  )









While many metrics can be used to determine which driver is best during “crunch time” only one driver can win the championship. Since the inception of the next-gen car in 2022, Ford has been the only manufacturer to win a championship. Logano has won two championships in 2022 and 2024. Blaney won once in 2023. The unpredictability of NASCAR makes it hard to determine if “crunch time” matters. At least the champions appeared on all the measured statistics.

title: Who are the best drivers in nascar through seven races in 2025?
text:
The NASCAR season is in full swing, and it is time to evaluate which drivers are performing the best. The schedule sees drivers take on more than just left turns with six road courses and one street course in downtown Chicago. The other tracks range from less than one mile to over 2.5 miles in length, with average speeds ranging from 110 to over 200 miles per hour. The schedule so far has included two drafting tracks (Daytona and Atlanta), one road course (Circuit of The Americas or COTA), two intermediate tracks (Las Vegas and Homestead-Miami), and two short tracks (Phoenix and Martinsville). This wide range of tracks offers wildly distinctive styles and results.
Through the first seven races of the season, there have been five different winners, with only one repeat winner: Christopher Bell in the No. 20 Toyota, who earned three consecutive wins in the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th races of the year. William Byron in the No. 24 Chevrolet opened the year with a win at Daytona, marking his second consecutive year with a win there. Bell went on to win at Atlanta, COTA, and Phoenix. Josh Berry in the No. 21 Ford won at Las Vegas, Kyle Larson in the No. 5 Chevrolet won at Homestead-Miami Speedway, and Denny Hamlin in the No. 11 Toyota won at Martinsville.
While leading laps is often crucial to winning races, it doesn’t always guarantee victory. Denny Hamlin has led almost 300 laps but has only won one race so far. Another way to evaluate the top drivers is by their respective manufacturer.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(janitor)
library(ggbump)
library(gt)

nascar2025<-read_csv("2025 NASCAR Season 7 Races - github(Sheet1).csv")

nascar2025 <- nascar2025 |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  remove_empty(which = c("rows", "cols"))

Encoding(nascar2025$driver) <- "latin1"
nascar2025$driver <- iconv(nascar2025$driver, "latin1", "ASCII", sub="")

lapleaders <- nascar2025 |>
  group_by(driver) |>
  summarise(
    total_laps_led = sum(led)
  ) |> 
  arrange(desc(total_laps_led))

top10lapleaders <- lapleaders |> 
  slice_head(n = 10)

dh <- top10lapleaders |> filter(grepl("Denny Hamlin", driver) == TRUE)
jl <- top10lapleaders |> filter(grepl("Joey Logano", driver) == TRUE)
wb <- top10lapleaders |> filter(grepl("William Byron", driver) == TRUE)
ggplot()+
  geom_bar(data = top10lapleaders, aes(x=reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill = "gray")+
  geom_bar(data=dh, aes(x = reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill ="red")+
  geom_bar(data=jl, aes(x = reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill="blue")+
  geom_bar(data=wb, aes(x = reorder(driver, total_laps_led), weight=total_laps_led), fill= "gold")+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(
    x="Driver", 
    y="Total Laps Led", 
    title="Top 10 Lap Leaders", 
    subtitle="Red is Toyota. Blue is Ford. Gold is Chevy.", 
    caption="Source: Racing Reference | By Blake Mace"
    )









Through seven races the results have varied. Leading laps also do not guarantee a driver will finish well. The top ten in laps led may not be the top ten in average finishes this year.


Code
avgfinishes<-nascar2025|> 
  group_by(driver)|>
  arrange(driver, race)|>
  mutate(avgfinishes = cummean(position))|>
  ungroup()

top10avgfinishers <-avgfinishes|>
  filter(race == 7)|>
  arrange(avgfinishes)|>
  slice_head(n = 10)

top10avgfinishers <- top10avgfinishers|> top_n(10, wt=race) |>
  select(number, driver, car, avgfinishes)

top10avgfinishers|> 
gt()|>
  cols_label(
    number = "Number",
    driver = "Driver",
    car = "Manufacturer",
    avgfinishes = "Average Finish"
    )|>
    tab_header(
    title = "What driver has the best average finish?",
    subtitle = "Red is the top Toyota driver, blue is the top Ford driver, gold is the top Chevy driver."
  )|>  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|> tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Blake Mace  |  **Source:** Racing Reference")
  )|> tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   )|>  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none")|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = number == "20")
  )|>
  tab_style(

      ),

      ),

Looking at the average finish, the top drivers from each manufacturer also shift. Now, considering the results of those same top ten drivers on a chart reveals that even a driver like Bell, who has won 3 out of 7 races this season, does not have the best average finish.


Code
drivers <- c("Kyle Larson", "William Byron", "Christopher Bell", "Chase Elliott", "Alex Bowman", "Denny Hamlin", "Tyler Reddick", "Chris Buescher", "Chase Briscoe", "Michael McDowell")
top10driverfinishes <- nascar2025|>
  filter(driver %in% drivers)|>
  select(position, number, driver, race)

ggplot()+ geom_bump(data=top10driverfinishes, aes(x=race, y=position, color=driver))+
geom_point(data=top10driverfinishes, aes(x=race, y=position, color=driver), size = 4)+
scale_color_manual(values = c("grey", "grey", "grey", "blue", "red", "grey", "gold", "grey", "grey", "grey")) +
  scale_y_reverse()+
  labs(
    title="Top 10 average finishers and their finishing positions", 
    subtitle="Using the top 10 average finishers to see their finishing positions",
    caption="Source: Racing Reference | By Blake Mace",
    y= "Finishing Position", 
    x= "Race") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_blank()
    ) |>
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









Christopher Bell, Alex Bowman, William Byron, Denny Hamlin, and Kyle Larson all appear in the two measured statistics. All these drivers, except Alex Bowman, have won a race. With only seven out of 36 races completed, the season still has a long way to go, but these statistics highlight which drivers have started the season with much needed momentum.
